Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Creating Plant Inspired Fragrences Via Fermentation
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to produce low-cost and customizable aromas that are inspired by plant extracts. The fragrance industry uses fragrant extracts from flowers and other plant materials as basic building blocks for haute-couture finished fragrances. These extracts are expensive due to the limited availability of suitable plant materials, and due to the fact that the extracts are too complicated to replicate by mixing pure chemicals. This project will generate novel fragrance blends via fermentation ("cultured aromas"). These cultured aromas will be customized for the exacting requirements of professional perfumers, offering a degree of creativity that does not exist with plant extracts. This technology will present a disruptive entry into the multi-billion dollar market for finished fragrances. Beyond fragrances, this technology will allow the development of new customizable extracts with the beneficial properties of plant extracts, including flavors, dyes, and antioxidant activity.

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to apply advanced synthetic biology tools to produce sustainable alternatives to complex plant extracts. Conventional metabolic engineering projects focus on the optimized production of a single target compound; this project instead will engineer microbial strains that produce a range of components found in high-value plant extracts used in the fragrance industry. The goal is to rapidly screen and characterize novel plant enzymes for use in conjunction with existing strains that produce key fragrance molecules. These novel enzymes are expected to produce multiple fragrance molecules and the profile of the resulting blends will be compared to those derived from plants via high throughput metabolomics. The cultured aroma blends can then be customized to a perfumers' specification by tuning the biosynthetic pathways.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many of the most valuable natural products are plant extracts that contain a wide array of active ingredients. These active ingredients are typically present in plants at very low yields and thus, the supply of these natural extracts is limited by the amount of plant material available, typically resulting in a high cost of production. Moreover, most of these specialty plant crops only grow in particular countries and thus compete with food crops for limited, arable land. To date, the field of metabolic engineering has successfully engineered microorganisms to produce isolated single compounds, but the production of complex mixtures that mimic the properties of natural plant extracts has not been demonstrated. In this proposal, we present a unique combination of synthetic biology approaches and high-resolution accurate mass spectrometry that enables the iterative improvement of engineered microorganisms that produce complex extracts. As a proof of concept, engineered the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae to produce unique fragrance blends comparable to natural flower extracts.

 

Over the course of this project, we introduced multiple fragrance pathways into yeast, producing fragrant molecules found in rose and other flowers. This work was done in Bioworks1, Ginkgo’s automated foundry for engineering organisms. Hundreds of different genes were chosen for synthesis, and novel yeast strains were designed, built, and tested in the foundry. Over the course of this work, we developed new software tools for sourcing new metabolic enzymes, improved our state-of-the-art LC-MS metabolomics platform, and developed new analytics methods for comparing different fragrant strains of yeast.

 

This work has been important to improving the way we use our foundry to rapidly engineer microbial strains that produce important natural products. Typical metabolic engineering projects focus on the production of a single key product via an engineered microorganism. For this project, our focus on multi-product complex fragrances gave us insight into the systems-level optimization of multi-product strains. Beyond fragrances, this will improve our ability to engineer complex microbial extracts for many different markets. The following news articles, written over the course of this project, provide more insight into our foundry and approach to fragrances.

 

1. Rutkin, A. “Would You Wear Yeast Perfume? Microbes Used to Brew Scent - 04 March 2015 - New Scientist” newscientist.com Available at http://www.newscientist.com/article/mg22530113.600-modified-yeast-perfume-what-the-future-smells-like.html

2. Lee, S. M. “This Startup Is Designing Yeast to Make Brand-New Scents, Flavors” Available at http://www.buzzfeed.com/stephaniemlee/this-startup-is-designing-yeast-to-make-brand-new-scents-fla

3. Stinson, L. “Move Over, Jony Ive—Biologists Are the Next Rock Star Designers” Available at http://www.wired.com/2015/11/move-over-jony-ivebiologists-are-the-next-rock-star-designers/

4. Lewis, T. “We Sampled Fragrances Made From Microbes and We‘re Convinced They’re the Future of the Industry” Available at http://www.businessinsider.com/we-tried-perfume-made-from-microbes-2015-10

 


Last Modified: 03/29/2016
Modified by: Patrick Boyle
